content:
My academic interests span a wide range of natural science questions, with the point of convergence being the development and application of computational methods - from data processing to exploratory visualization to modeling. At the moment, two research areas of focus are 1. elucidating transcript, protein and metabolite level changes accompanying root senescence and 2. identification of gene expression patterns in nutrient perturbed crop plants.
Previously at Leibniz Lung Center, I developed methods for error modeling mass spectrometry data and conceptualized a novel metric for determining lipidome homology. Prior to that, at the National Center for Biological Sciences, I applied sequence alignment algorithms for small molecule structure comparison and developed a stochastic model of Transcription. At the Center for Cellular and Molecular Biology, the focus was to reconstruct microbial metabolic pathways from publicly available databases and analyze the network topology.
Away from work, I enjoy bicyling, running and reading. Favorite book is To Kill a Mocking Bird by Harper Lee. Favorite running event is Tromsø Polar Night Halfmarathon.

title: nara

summary: Transcriptome profiling in root tissues revealed upregulation of several NAC-, WRKY- and AP2-type transcription factors
title: A genetically-determined sequence of physiological processes defines developmental root senescence

summary: Crops grown in nutrient deficient soils adapt novel strategies to acclimatize. One such adaptation is investigated in this study
title: Effect of Silica in Potassium deficient barley

summary: Application of LUX Score to seperate Cancer from non-Cancer tissues
title: Lipidomes of lung cancer and tumour-free lung tissues reveal distinct molecular signatures for cancer differentiation, age, inflammation, and pulmonary emphysema

summary: This thesis fills the knowledge gap in developing computational methods that offer better insights into the lipidomics data
title: Development of Computational Methods for Systematic Analysis of Lipids and Lipidomes

summary: A data analysis workflow to compare lipid structural differences between tumor and alveolar tissues using LUX Score.
title: Analysis of Lung Tissue Lipidomes of Cancer Patients using the LUX Score

content: LUX Score is an unbiased metric to measure global differences between a pair of lipidomes. It is based on structural similarity between constituent lipids. It is a distance measure, always between 0 and 1, indicating complete-similarity and complete-dissimilarity respectively
summary: LUX Score is an unbiased metric to measure global differences between a pair of lipidomes
title: The LUX Score: A Metric for Lipidome Homology

title: LUX Score - Cheminformatics Approach to Compute Lipidome Homology
Structure based exploratory tool for lipidomics

summary: Gm1 peptide shows a high level of antibacterial activity. Gm1 and ΔGm1 Gm1 block the action of free endotoxin, and do not have citotoxic effects in human blood cells.
title: Galleria mellonella native and analogue peptides Gm1 and ∆Gm1. II) Anti-bacterial and anti-endotoxic effects

summary: Informatics resources that account for chemical similarity between lipid molecules as basis for a qualitative comparison of lipidomes
title: BLAST inspired global analysis tool box for lipidomes
Studies on Herbicidal and Anti-Fungal Activity of Drechslera puttapathii sp. nov.

summary: In this study, a newly discovered fungal species, Drechslera puttaparthii sp.nov is tested for herbicidal and anti-fungal activity. The fungus is cultured in Bioreactor and Rotary shaker at varying pH for extraction of crude metabolite. The crude metabolite produced by the fungus is then tested for herbicidal and anti-fungal activity. Parthenium hyterophorus and Neurospora species were chosen to study herbicidal and anti-fungal activity respectively. This present preliminary investigation revealed significant herbicidal activity and anti-fungal activity as observed by wilting of Parthenium plant and inhibition of Neurospora colonies on agar plate by Drechslera metabolites. Best results were obtained by growing Drechslera puttaparthii sp.nov at pH 5.4 on Czapex-dox medium. Further work to isolate the compounds responsible for herbicidal and anti-fungal activity is in progress
title: Studies on cellulose degradation by Drechslera puttaparthii by semi-solid fermentation technique
